articles.title: South Africa's president to 'reset strategic relations' with Trump at White House meeting
articles.description: South Africa's President Cyril Ramaphosa traveled to Washington, D.C., on Monday and will meet with President Donald Trump at the White House on Wednesday to discuss "global issues of interest" amid strained relations.

articles.author: New York Post
articles.title: To end the war in Ukraine, make Beijing's bankrolling of Russia's war machine hurt
articles.description: If President Trump wants a true end to the war in Ukraine, he needs to unleash secondary sanctions on those who are keeping Russia's war machine chugging.
articles.content:
If President Donald Trump wants lasting peace in Ukraine, he needs to unleash secondary sanctions on the countries keeping Vladimir Putin’s bloody war going.
Trump left Monday’s call with Putin in an optimistic mood, posting that the chat “went very ... [2126 chars]

articles.author: The New York Times
articles.title: SPAC Deals Are Back, This Time With a Trump Bump
articles.description: President Trump’s associates and crypto entrepreneurs are rushing back to the market for the once-hot, but mostly troubled, investment vehicles called special purpose acquisition companies.
articles.content:
Celebrity endorsements, companies with no clear plans, investors left feeling burned: The pandemic-era boom in risky investments called SPACs was an investment craze many would surely like to forget.
Well, it’s back. There has been a flurry of SPAC d... [592 chars]

articles.title: Donald Trump 'surprised' public wasn't told about Biden's cancer diagnosis 'a long time ago'
articles.description: Mr Trump also suggested at least one of the doctors treating Mr Biden had previously found the the former US president to be "cognitively fine".
articles.content:
Donald Trump has said he is "surprised" the public wasn't "notified a long time ago" after Joe Biden was diagnosed with an aggressive form of prostate cancer.

articles.title: Trump must make China pay for the death and misery of COVID
articles.description: Punitive measures against the Chinese economy won’t bring back the victims of COVID — but they must not be forgotten: That's part of the moral imperative to constraining Beijing.
articles.content:
When a nation bears the blame for more than 7 million deaths worldwide, what is Washington going to do?
More than 1.2 million Americans died as a result of a plague that began in China.
